title: Cramér-Rao Lower Bound: A Step-by-Step Guide
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll demonstrate how to apply the Cramér-Rao lower bound (CR bound) to a specific problem.

problem.statementHtml: Suppose we have a random sample of size n from a normal distribution with mean θ and variance σ^2. We want to find the minimum variance unbiased estimator (MVUE) for θ.
hints: Hint: Start by finding the MVUE

workedExample.problemHtml: Find the CR bound for the sample mean \bar{x} = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n x_i.

steps.explanation: The score function measures how much the log likelihood changes when θ is perturbed.

steps.description: Compute the variance of the score
steps.explanation: We're interested in the variance of the score, which will help us find the CR bound.
Now we can apply the CR bound to find a lower bound for the variance of the sample mean.
Since we've found the CR bound, we can conclude that the sample mean is an MVUE for θ.

workedExample.finalAnswer: The CR bound for the sample mean is \frac{\sigma^2}{n}.

intuition: The Cramér-Rao lower bound provides a fundamental limit on the precision of any unbiased estimator. By applying it to our problem, we've shown that the sample mean is an MVUE and has a minimum variance.

problemHtml: Suppose we have a random variable X ~ N(\mu, \sigma^2). We want to find the CRB for estimating \mu.
steps: [ {"stepNumber": 1, "description": "Find the log-likelihood function", "mathHtml": "\\[ l(\\theta; x) = -\\frac{1}{2}\\log(2\\pi\\sigma^2) - \\frac{(x-\\mu)^2}{2\\sigma^2} \\]", "explanation": "This is the starting point for our CRB calculation." }, {"stepNumber": 2, "description": "Take the derivative of the log-likelihood function with respect to \\theta", "mathHtml": "\\[ \\frac{\\partial}{\\partial \\mu} l(\\mu; x) = -\\frac{x-\\mu}{\\sigma^2} \\]", "explanation": "This gives us the score function." }, {"stepNumber": 3, "description": "Find the expected value of the score function", "mathHtml": "\\[ E\\left[\\frac{\\partial}{\\partial \\mu} l(\\mu; X)\\right] = -E\\left[\\frac{X-\\mu}{\\sigma^2}\\right] \\]", "explanation": "This is the expected value of the score function, which we'll use in our CRB calculation." }, {"stepNumber": 4, "description": "Use the CRB formula", "mathHtml": "\\[ \\frac{1}{\\text{Var}[\hat{\\mu}]} \geq E\\left[\\frac{(X-\\mu)^2}{\\sigma^2}\\right] \\]", "explanation": "This is our final answer, which gives us the CRB for estimating \\mu." } ],

title: Cramér-Rao Lower Bound: Variance Bound and Efficiency
contentHtml: In this worked example, we'll demonstrate how to apply the Cramér-Rao lower bound (CRB) to find a variance bound for an estimator.

problem.statementHtml: Suppose we have a random sample X_1, ..., X_n from a normal distribution N(\theta, 1). We want to find the variance bound for an unbiased estimator \hat{\theta}.
problem.solutionHtml:
We'll use the CRB formula:

  • Find the Fisher information matrix I(\theta)
  • Evaluate the inverse of I(\theta) at \hat{\theta}
  • Use the result to find the variance bound

workedExample.problemHtml: We have a random sample X_1, ..., X_n from N(\theta, 1). We want to find the variance bound for the sample mean \hat{\theta} = (X_1 + ... + X_n)/n.

steps.description: Find the Fisher information matrix I(\theta)
steps.explanation: The Fisher information matrix measures the amount of information about \theta contained in the data.

steps.description: Evaluate the inverse of I(\theta) at \hat{\theta}
steps.explanation: The inverse of the Fisher information matrix gives us the variance bound.

steps.description: Use the result to find the variance bound
steps.explanation: The CRB formula gives us the variance bound for the sample mean.

intuition: The Cramér-Rao lower bound provides a fundamental limit on the precision of an estimator.
